awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Role of Polymer Sequence on Penetrant Transport in Charged Brushes
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecular-scale brushes, created by grafting polymers to surfaces, can be used to control the properties of the surface, including its charge, wettability, permeability, and response to environmental conditions such as salt concentration. In principle, polymer brush-coated surfaces are potentially transformative technologies for important applications in drug delivery, chemical separation processes, and water purification. Selectively controlling the transport of small molecules and particles into and out of the brush is necessary for these applications, but the ability to do so remains a persistent challenge because it is difficult to tune the structure of the brush. This research project will develop a route to control brush conformation and its response to environmental conditions by engineering the sequence of monomers that compose the polymer brush. The team will relate the structure of the engineered brushes to how small molecules and particles move through them under static and flow conditions. This research will address a critical knowledge gap by providing understanding of how the sequence of charged monomers affect the transport of penetrants, leading to improved membrane coatings for water and biologic drug purification. The project team will disseminate these results to scientists and engineers in Houston’s petrochemical, biomedical, and materials industries through local meetings, including the Texas Soft Matter Meeting. In parallel, they will develop educational outreach videos on water purification in multiple languages spoken in the Houston metro area, and present hands-on demonstrations for the general public at the Houston Energy Festival.

The objective of this project is to develop a fundamental understanding of the influence of polymer sequence on transport within charged polymer brushes. Team members from two nearby universities in Houston will integrate complementary expertise in sequence-controlled polymer synthesis (Marciel – Rice University), neutron scattering applied to brushes (Conrad – University of Houston), and state-of-the-art microscopy techniques (Marciel and Conrad) to address three specific aims: (1) determine the role of polymer sequence on brush properties, (2) identify mechanisms that dictate coupling between penetrant and charged polymer brush dynamics, and (3) understand the effects of flow on out-of-equilibrium penetrant transport in charged polymer brushes. Protein engineering methodologies will be used to synthesize sequence-controlled charged polymers with isotopic labelling for grazing-incidence small angle neutron scattering (GI-SANS) and neutron reflectivity (NR) experiments to measure brush conformation and height in equilibrium and out-of-equilibrium conditions. Penetrant transport coefficients will be measured using confocal and total internal reflection fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (TIR-FCS), exploiting vertical sensitivity to distinguish transport inside and outside brushes and tested against theories for diffusion and dispersion within polymer matrices and in porous media. Together, these studies will provide new insight into the role of charge fraction and spacing on the diffusive and flow-driven transport of penetrants in charged brushes, which will pave the way for the design of advanced responsive surfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project outcomes 

Intellectual Merit:

The focus of this NSF grant was to investigate the effects of polymer chemistry on the motion of particles within charged polymer brushes, which consist of charged polymers end-tethered to solid-supports. This scenario is encountered in a wide range of applications, including water treatment and purification, and in separations and sensing applications for the purification of biologics. The performance of these materials depends on controlling the physical properties that manifest at the interface, which requires understanding how structural and environmental parameters influence brush conformation. Thus, we used advanced synthesis, light scattering, microscopy techniques to study the change in brush height with varying monomer chemistry, pH, and salt concentration.

The outcomes from our project were focused on two main areas.

First, we used surface-initiated copper(0) controlled radical polymerization (SI-CuCRP) to synthesize a series of random copolymer brushes with basic ((2-(dimethylamino)ethyl acrylate, DMAEA) and neutral (2-hydroxyethyl acrylate, HEA) monomers with varying fractions of ionizable monomer. We showed that this synthetic strategy enables excellent control over dry brush height, grafting density, and ionizable monomer fraction. We observed a pH-dependent change in brush height consistent with the stimuli-responsive behavior of weak PEBs (in which the charge state is dependent on pH). Moreover, the brush conformation exhibited a direction-dependent change (hysteresis) with pH. Both brush height and hysteresis were found to increase with the fraction of ionizable monomers. These trends confirm the non-uniform charge distribution predicted for weak PEBs. They also, intriguingly, suggest that the hysteresis arises from a direction-dependent change in charge state at the brush periphery due to the formation of a hydrophobic periphery.

The ability to precisely control brush conformation through pH modulation underpins drug delivery and purification of biological molecules. In many practical settings, however, there are significant amounts of salt present. We investigated the influence of salt concentration on brush height and hysteresis as a function of  ionizable monomer fraction and pH. We uncovered a salt-dependent, non-monotonic hysteretic behavior and showed that charge state, set by solution conditions, dictates whether charged brushes exhibit weak or strong polyelectrolyte behavior. Our system enabled access to low charge density brushes to directly test a prominent theory for weak PEBs that is only applicable at near neutral conditions. The scaling of brush height with ionic strength deviated from theoretical predictions across regimes of ionic strength. These findings indicate that real systems have excluded volume interactions and may not be as strongly stretched as assumed by theory.

Second, to further advance these systems for transport applications, we quantified motion of a probe molecule inside our PDMAEA brush using a 3D single molecule tracking method. For this study, we designed PEB brushes with swollen brush heights > 500 nm to ensure probe motion could be tracked within the brush using optical microscopy. We observed two distinct populations, which we termed unconfined and confined. The unconfined population exhibited diffusive motion parallel to the grafting surface and subdiffusive motion perpendicular to the grafting surface, whereas the confined population exhibited subdiffusive motion in all directions. This study showed for the first time that internal brush structure controls the molecular scale transport mechanisms in PEBs.

Broader Impacts:

This proposal supported the training of 1 PhD student (who defended his PhD in April 2024 and started a position as a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Virginia) in experimental methods in soft matter science, including brush polymer synthesis, microscopy, and advanced scattering methods. The PI participated in outreach efforts hosted by Rice University for high school girls (~20 students) interested in physics and engineering. This program has been effective in improving high school physics outcomes for young women (2022 and 2023). Additionally, the PI participated with local industry by presenting at the Energy Polymer Research Group (EPG) 2022 Spring Technical Meeting, which is a professional organization founded in Houston dedicated to advancing polymer technologies. PI also organized meetings on soft matter to bring together local members of the community throughout the state of Texas (2021).
